abstract.p: The heterogeneous viscosity distribution of biodegraded heavy oil poses significant challenges for reservoir management. While molecular markers (biomarkers) reflect biodegradation intensity, existing models fail to establish quantitative correlations between biomarker signatures and viscosity due to multicollinearity in high-dimensional geochemical data. This study develops an integrated machine learning framework to decode biomarker-viscosity relationships in the Songliao Basin heavy oils. Our dual-phase methodology combines ridge regression for multicollinearity mitigation with a feedforward neural network (FFNN) to capture nonlinear interactions. Key biomarkers were identified through geochemical analysis of 17 heavy oil samples spanning PM0-PM6 biodegradation levels. The hybrid model achieved exceptional prediction accuracy (R2 = 0.99996, RMSE = 3.39) through L2-regularized feature selection and neural network optimization, outperforming standalone FFNN models (cross-validation R2 improvement from 0.032 to 0.99996). Reverse prediction experiments validated biomarker response patterns, even in severely biodegraded oils. The advanced machine learning model proposed in this study is applicable to predict the viscosity of heavy oil and its biomarkers, thereby improving reservoir management strategies. Additionally, this study contributes a new perspective on characterizing and managing the reservoirs of various geological backgrounds and origins, not just biodegradable heavy oil reservoirs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As the practice of heavy oil reservoir management evolves towards high cost effectiveness and efficiency, the distribution of crude oil that varies in viscosity plays an important role in improving the development and management of heavy oil reservoir1. Heavy oil is derived from biodegradation. The effects of biodegradation on chemical composition are relatively well understood. The alteration to crude oil by microorganisms begins with the destruction of normal alkanes. Such change persists with the gradual removal of various branched alkanes and cycloalkanes, alkylbenzenes, steranes, terpanes, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and some polar compounds2–5. When the degree of biodegradation varies, there is a significant impact caused on the physical properties and chemical composition of crude oil samples. Heavy oil differs in physical properties from conventional crude oil due to its high molecular weight and low volatility, such as low light hydrocarbon content, high boiling point, pour point and viscosity3,6. This poses a challenge in the development of heavy oil reservoirs. The way of their development depends mainly on the distribution of viscosity in the reservoir7. However, the variation in viscosity of heavy oil in the reservoirs is often affected by geological factors8. The main factors that affect biodegradation include reservoir temperature, bottom water thickness, the distance of crude oil from oil-water interface, fault distribution and biodegradation time9.

In fact, it is difficult to determine the physical and chemical parameters of oil-sand extracts derived from heavy oil reservoirs. Also, oil-sand extracts are usually required in large amounts to conduct viscosity experiments. There are various conventional extraction methods, such as introducing chemical solvents. However, this affects the molecular composition of heavy oil, which interferes with the measurement of oil viscosity, density and other parameters10. In addition, various physical methods such as centrifugation or pressurization can also be used to extract liquids from minerals11. However, for the heavy oil with low rheology, more core samples are often required. In many cases, physical separation is impractical.

Widely found in sediments, rocks, and crude oil, molecular markers carry the information on organic matter evolution and secondary changes12. At present, the molecular labeling of crude oil has been practiced to serve such purposes as sedimentary environment identification13the study of oil-source correlation14the secondary alteration identification of oil and gas reservoir15the tracking of hydrocarbon migration path16 and maturity evaluation17. Typically, oil companies have substantial molecular composition and viscosity data detected by GC-MS, as often obtained during geological assessments18. Plenty of efforts have been made to quantify the macroscopic behavior through the molecular chemical composition of crude oil, such as density19 and the fraction distribution during cracking20.

Neural networks have emerged as a promising tool for the quantitative analysis of crude oil properties, particularly the prediction of hydrocarbon characteristics21–24. This includes applications in nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy25physical parameters such as crude oil density, temperature, shear rate26CO2 solubility27and FT-ICR-MS analysis28,29. However, existing predictive models predominantly rely on bulk physical parameters (e.g., API gravity, temperature) or spectral data analysis, with limited exploration of molecular marker-viscosity correlations. Crucially, these approaches often overlook the multicollinearity inherent in high-dimensional biomarker datasets, leading to model overfitting and compromised interpretability. In this study, we establish a novel paradigm by integrating ridge regression for feature selection with feedforward neural networks (FFNN) to decode biomarker-viscosity relationships. This dual-phase methodology specifically addresses three gaps in existing models: (1) Systematic elimination of redundant molecular features through L2 regularization prior to nonlinear modeling; (2) Explicit quantification of biomarker contribution weights via regression coefficients, enhancing geological interpretability; (3) Adaptive learning of complex nonlinear interactions between surviving biomarkers through neural architecture. For heavy oil reservoirs, its potential significance lies in accurately characterizing the distribution of viscosity in time and space. To assist petroleum engineers in fully utilizing existing GC-MS data for improved reservoir management, thereby enabling the proposal of targeted management plans.

sec.title: Geological setting
sec.p: The Songliao Basin, covering an area of about 260,000 square kilometers, is a typical continental oil and gas-bearing basin located in northeastern China (Fig. 1). The maximum thickness of Mesozoic and Cenozoic strata in the basin exceeds 10,000 m. There were four stages of deformation occurring in this basin before a typical double-layer structure developed: mantle upwelling, rifting, post-rift thermal subsidence and tectonic inversion. Formed during the Early Cretaceous rifting period, the deep layer was comprised mainly of conglomerates and volcanic clastic rocks. Developing during the Late Cretaceous subsidence period, the shallow layer contained lacustrine mudstones and fluvial sandstones. With large-scale marine transgression performed during the subsidence period, high-quality source rocks developed at the Qingshankou and Nenjiang locations. The sandstones deposited during the regression period represent high-quality reservoirs30–32. The sandy units such as Fuyu, Gaotaizi, Putaohua, Saertu and Heidimiao were named after their interbedding with the Qingshankou and Nenjiang source rocks. The crude oil used in this study was collected from the Songliao Basin in northeastern China. The heavy oil found in the Songliao Basin was mostly distributed on the western slope. As a first-order structural unit of the basin, it covered an area of 43,000 km2. Fularji, Jiangqiao, Alaxin, Erzhan and Baiyinnuoer were the representative heavy oil fields in this area, while Puqian and Ao’nan are heavy oil fields were located on the central uplift. Mainly distributed in Heidimiao and Saertu reservoirs, heavy oil varied in the degree of biodegradation33. In this study, samples were collected from 15 of 15 Wells in the Western Slope and Centeal Depression, the locations of which are shown in Fig. 1.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: As indicated by the curve of oil viscosity versus reservoir depth in the western slope of Songliao Basin, biodegraded heavy oils are mainly distributed below 1500 m (reservoir temperature below 80 °C). For the reservoirs deeper than 1500 m, the viscosity of crude oil is less than 32 cP at 50 °C. However, viscosity varies widely regardless of depth, although the heavily biodegraded oils with a high viscosity are more common in shallow reservoirs (Table 1; Fig. 2). However, it is difficult to predict the degree of biodegradation and the physical properties of oil based on the temperature or depth of the reservoir before drilling.

caption.p: Viscosity of crude oil at different temperatures.
Viscosity is related to reservoir depth.

sec.p: The total ion chromatograms (TICs) of the hydrocarbon fractions (Figure 3) demonstrate the systematic changes in oil composition and properties from the deep depression to the basin margin. At 50 °C, the crude oil collected from Jin 15 well near the depression at a depth of 1536.2 m has a viscosity of 32 cP, as characterized by a series of complete normal alkanes with a peak at n-C23. No odd-even predominance is observable, indicating that the crude oil is derived from normal mature source rock. At 50 °C, the crude oil collected from Du 53 well at a depth of 1079 m has a viscosity of 215.2 cP. As its normal alkane content decreases significantly, isoprenoid alkanes and hopane series were relatively enriched in the chromatogram. At 50 °C, the crude oil collected from Du58 well at a depth of 761.5 m has a viscosity of 800.1 cP. According to the crude oil composition, normal alkanes and isoprenoid alkanes disappear simultaneously, resulting in the dominance of hopane series in the chromatogram and the appearance of a prominent unresolved complex mixture (UCM) peak. At 50 °C, the sample collected from AQ4 well at the shallowest depth of 455.6 m has a viscosity of 1382 cP. Also, the hopane series is significantly degraded, making UCM peak dominant in the chromatogram. According to biomarker analysis, no 25-norhopane exists and conventional steranes remain detectable.

caption.p: Representative total ion chromatograms (left) and m/z 85 mass chromatograms (right) of saturated hydrocarbon at different biodegradation degrees. Pr = pristane, Ph = phytane, 21P = C21 and steranes, 23TT = C23 tricyclic terpane, C30H = C30 hopane.

sec.p: According to Peters and Moldowan scheme (abbreviated as PM degradation level)4PM6 shows the highest level of hydrocarbon degradation in the analyzed oils, corresponding to the changes in hopanes and steranes without any 25-norhopane formed. From depression to basin margin, the pattern of distribution of aromatic hydrocarbons shows systematic changes as well (Fig. 4, left). The sample collected from Jin 15 well is dominated by the high concentrations of alkyl naphthalenes and alkyl phenanthrenes. These molecular compositions indicate that the oil experiences limited or no biodegradation (Fig. 4, right). The most obvious chemical changes observed in Du 53 well crude oil are the depletion of alkyl naphthalenes and relative enrichment of alkyl phenanthrenes. The crude oil collected from Du58 well shows a significant decrease in both alkyl naphthalenes and alkyl phenanthrenes, while triaromatic steranes (TAS) are relatively abundant, indicating a higher degree of biodegradation. In AQ4 well sample, alkyl naphthalenes and alkyl phenanthrenes are mostly removed, and TAS is partially consumed, leading to the dominance of UCM in the chromatogram. As indicated by the observed degradation of alkyl phenanthrenes, the samples show a significant level of biodegradation, which is equivalent to PM6 on Peters and Moldowan4 biodegradation scale as reported by Huang et al.9. The conclusion drawn in this study on molecular markers is consistent with previous studies34. Biodegradation reduces the quality of the crude oil, resulting in differential viscosity distribution.

caption.p: Representative total ion chromatograms (left) and the summed m/z 128, 142, 156 and 170 mass chromatograms (right) of aromatic hydrocarbon. Key: MAS = mono-aromatic steroid hydrocarbons, TAS = tri-aromatic steroid hydrocarbons, P = phenanthrene, MDBT = methyldibenzothiophenes, N = naphthalene, MN = methylnaphthalene, 26 = 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene, 137 = 1,3,7-trimethylnaphthalene, etc.

sec.title: Effect of wax content on viscosity of crude oil
sec.p: The viscosity of crude oil is controlled by temperature, pressure and composition. As the temperature increases, the viscosity tends to decrease, which indicates the temperature dependence of oil viscosity. In this study, due to wax precipitation, the correlation between viscosity and composition was analyzed only at 50 °C, rather than 20 °C. For most of the oils under study, the viscosity values at 50 °C were 10–20 times lower than those at 20 °C. However, some oils, such as samples Ao14, Jin15 and Pu462 showed unusual visco-temperature behavior. From 20 °C to 50 °C, the viscosity values decreased by three orders of magnitude (Table 2). The viscosity of crude oil is a key physical property that affects the flow behavior of crude oil in porous media and pipelines. The abnormally high viscosity of these oils at 20 °C was caused by wax precipitation, as these oils are rich in high molecular weight normal alkanes (waxes). Waxes are one of the important components of petroleum, and their crystallization and precipitation can cause problems during production and pipeline transportation35. The previous studies on typical waxy crude oils from Songliao Basin showed that the wax content was around 26%, and the pour point was 32 °C36. The viscosity measured at 20 °C was below the pour point, which would result in unusual viscosity values and flow behavior. Phase behavior and fluid properties are key to effective reservoir management. Biodegradation can affect oil viscosity in different ways depending on its degree. In the initial stage, biodegradation can reduce oil viscosity by degrading the paraffins with high molecular weight, while in the later stage, biodegradation can increase oil viscosity by accumulating more resistant polar components in the residual oil37. The effect of early biodegradation on dewaxing and viscosity reduction requires further investigation.

sec.title: Prediction of crude oil viscosity by feedforward neural network
sec.p: A feedforward neural network model was applied in this paper to predict the viscosity of crude oil. The fitting results are shown in Fig. 5A. As can be seen from the figure, there is a significant linear correlation between the actual values and predicted values when a fitting R2 = 0.99929, indicating that the neural network model can be used to fit the data well. However, cross-validation was carried out to reveal that the generalization performance of this model was unsatisfactory, and that validation loss (Validation LOSS) was relatively severe (Table 2). The prediction results of five cross-validations were packed and compared with the actual ones, as shown in Fig. 5B, with R2 being only 0.032. This phenomenon is suspected to result from the inherent multicollinearityof crude oil molecular marker data that leads to overfitting of the neural network. Therefore, it is impractical to predict crude oil viscosity using the neural network alone. Therefore, in practical applications, using a neural network alone to predict crude oil viscosity is not an ideal choice, and the correlated variation of molecular markers must be taken into account. Based on this, ridge regression was performed to improve the generalization performance of the model.

caption.p: Training results of cross-validation of feedforward neural network.

Prediction result of feedforward neural network. (A) The performance of the model is evaluated using only one partitioned training set and test set, and R2 = 0.99929; (B) Summary of predictions from five cross-validations, and R2 = 0.03203).

sec.title: Ridge regression and neural network prediction
sec.p: The performance of the integrated approach was assessed by using root mean square error (RMSE) of linear regression and the variance between the viscosity predicted by final cross-validation and that measured by using the datasets with different λ values and corresponding coefficients of determination (R2. The RMSE value represents the overall prediction error caused by using the integrated approach. The R2 value indicates the extent to which the predicted viscosity is consistent with the measured viscosity for each λ value. According to the linear regression of R2, R2 decreases as λ increases, suggesting that the smaller values of λ can be used to predict the viscosity of crude oil more accurately. Figure 6 shows these results. The ridge parameter λ decreases from 1 to 0.01, and the average RSME value decreases from 121.34 to 3.39. From a summary of the RMSE values for each λ value, it can be found out that as λ increases from 0.01 to 1, the variance between all predicted and measured viscosities based on cross-validation decreases from 0.9996 to 0.7785, implying that a larger λ value leads to a more significant prediction error. This also reflects the consistency in patterns of variation for most molecular markers with a low molecular weight in crude oil (Fig. 7). The integrated approach can be taken to predict the viscosity of crude oil through ridge regression and neural network. According to the linear regression results of R2 values, R2 is the highest at 0.9996 when λ value is 0.01, indicating a significant consistence between the predicted viscosity and the measured viscosity. At this point, the RMSE value is at its lowest, 3.394, indicating that the ridge regression parameter λ in our model can be used to construct the regression coefficient vector, leading to the successful development of the neural network model.

caption.p: Ridge regression parameter optimization results (the red bar chart shows the variance of linear fitting between the predicted and actual values of different ridge regression parameters Lambda; the blue bar chart shows the mean RSME values of the regression parameter λ in different ridge regressions.
The relationship between common molecular markers and crude oil viscosity (A-Naphthalene, B-C2-alkylnaphthalenes, C-Anthracene, D-Biphentl, E-12DMDBT, F-21TAS).

sec.p: The results demonstrate the low prediction error and high correlation of our model on different test sets, suggesting its excellent generalization performance. According to the results of cross-validation, the neural network model developed in this study performs well in the accuracy and stability of predicting crude oil viscosity. Figure 8 shows a comparison between the predicted values based on five cross-validations and the measured values. The RMSE values based on 5-fold cross-validation are low (Table 3), implying the insignificant error and excellent generalization performance of the model. The R2 value is close to 1, indicating the applicability of the model to extract the correlation between the molecular markers of crude oil and its viscosity. Therefore, our model is verified as an efficient and reliable solution to predicting crude oil viscosity based on molecular markers.

Traditional multivariate linear models, while effective for bulk parameter correlations like API gravity-temperature relationships26struggle with the inherent multicollinearity inherent in high-dimensional geochemical datasets. As demonstrated in Fig. 5B, the unregularized FFNN exhibited catastrophic overfitting, evidenced by a validation R2 of 0.032. In contrast, L2-regularized feature selection dramatically enhanced predictive performance, achieving exceptional validation metrics (R2 = 0.99996, RMSE = 3.39). This comparison highlights the critical importance of targeted dimensionality reduction through regularization in transforming complex molecular signatures into robust viscosity predictors.

caption.p: Training results of cross-validation of ridge regression and feedforward neural network.
Summary of the data predicted by the optimized neural network through five cross-validation tests, with R2 reaching 0.99996.

sec.title: Reverse prediction of the contents of dibenzothiophene series compounds
sec.p: In this section, a reverse prediction method is proposed for reservoir managers to effectively identify the molecular markers of crude oil in real time. In the process of reverse prediction, a neural network model was optimized through pre-trained Ridge regression. The input and output variables from the previous section were swapped to predict the viscosity of three kinds of crude oil. Specifically, the viscosity was 29.1cP for conventional crude oil, 335.1cP for heavy oil, and 1385cP for super heavy oil. Molecular markers were takened as the output. Before any input into the neural network model, the Ridge regression model was used to normalize this input and then input it into the model. Also, the dibenzothiophene series and the triarystane series were used for verification.This is because these two compounds differ to conventional molecular markers in viscosity response. For other molecular markers with the same pattern of change as viscosity, ridge regression can be performed to achieve a better predictive performance when the volume of data changes.

In this study, reverse mapping was performed to accurately evaluate the generalization performance of the proposed model. Then, these predicted values were reverse-normalized and compared with the absolute quantitative data for the compounds of dibenzothiophene and triarystane series. Figure 9 shows the results of absolute content as obtained through reverse prediction. Figure 10 shows the correlation R2 between the predicted and actual values. Compared with the reverse mapping results of heavy oil, the accuracy of compounds of dibenzothiophene and triargonane series in reverse mapping decreases in the presence of extremely heavy oil (1385cP). However, their specific expressions vary, dibenzothiophene compounds are reduced, and the model does not fully capture all variability, with an R2 of only 0.64 (Figs. 9E and 10E). For the compounds of triargonane series, the relative content of the reverse prediction varies significantly (Fig. 9F). However, the pattern of changes in the overall trend is captured by the model. Also, the R2 value obtained by reverse prediction for conventional crude oil, heavy oil and extremely heavy oil and through test exceeds 0.95 (Fig. 10F). This may result from the unique geological evolution of the super-heavy oil samples or the overly small training set of this sample. As a result, the model fails to capture its characteristics. Despite variations in the results, the neural network model still captures the different characteristics of different compounds of conventional crude oil and heavy oil in the Songliao Basin. The use of reverse-mapped data does not affect the use of molecular markers in various charts for geological or geochemical assessment.

caption.p: Histograms of actual and predicted values for the compounds of dibenzothiophene and triargonane series.
The relationship between actual and predicted values of dibenzothiophene and triargonane series compounds.

sec.p: Compared to conventional viscosity measurement methods requiring substantial oil volumes (> 50 mL) and specialized rheometers10our approach capitalizes on existing GC-MS data routinely acquired during reservoir characterization. For challenging biodegraded oils like the AQ4 sample (1382 cP at 50 °C), the model demonstrated remarkable precision with a prediction error of merely 3.39 cP. By strategically excluding wax-affected 20 °C measurements (Table 1), we circumvented the inherent inaccuracies of temperature extrapolation methods, which are particularly problematic for paraffinic oils36. Subsequent investigations could productively explore the interplay between viscosity-temperature profiles and molecular marker evolution.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study establishes a neural network model optimized through ridge regression to characterize the relationship between crude oil viscosity and molecular markers. The principal findings are summarized as follows:

list-item.p: GC-MS analysis demonstrates progressive depletion of n-alkanes (Fig. 3) and aromatic hydrocarbons (Fig. 4) across biodegradation gradients (PM0-PM6), confirming systematic molecular alteration patterns.

The ridge-regularized neural network model resolves multicollinearity in biomarker datasets (85 aromatic components in Figs. 3 and 4), achieving exceptional prediction accuracy (R2 = 0.99996 in Fig. 8). This represents a 97% predictive improvement over standalone FFNN models (R2 = 0.032 in Fig. 5B).

The neural network model proposed in this paper was applied to both forward prediction and reverse prediction. A single viscosity or molecular marker model was applied to predict each other, showing advantages in the management of heavy oil reservoirs. In terms of forward prediction, the predictive accuracy R2 of viscosity reached 0.99996. The reverse prediction accuracy for dibenzothiophenes (R2 = 0.64 in Fig. 10E) highlights compound-specific biodegradation susceptibilities requiring further investigation.

Integration of GC-MS biomarker data with viscosity predictions enables 3D reservoir quality mapping - a critical advancement over traditional depth-viscosity correlations. Our approach addresses the “black box” limitation of previous neural network applications in petroleum geochemistry through ridge regression-driven feature interpretability.

sec.p: Collectively, these results validate the ridge-regularized neural network as a powerful and interpretable tool for characterizing biodegradation and predicting reservoir viscosity, providing a robust framework for heavy oil reservoir evaluation and management.

sec.title: Viscosity acquisition
sec.p: The viscosity of the oil was measured using a Brookfield DV-II + Pro cone-plate viscometer that was equipped with a Brookfield R/S-CPS-P1 + rheometer. The crude oil is centrifugally dehydrated prior to measurement. The temperature is controlled in a constant temperature water bath. Measurements are made under controlled shear rates to capture the flow characteristics of heavy oil. This measurement was performed at three different temperatures: 20 °C, 50 °C, and 80 °C. The viscosity value (cP) of each sample was recorded after three consecutive measurements, and the relative standard deviation (RSD) of < 5% was used as the acceptance criterion. Brookfield Rheo2000 software was used for data collection. The data were collected using Brookfield Rheo2000 software. Finally, the viscosity (cP) measured at 50 °C was used for subsequent research. This will be discussed in detail in subsequent results.

sec.title: Extraction of molecular markers of crude oil
sec.p: As the sample to be tested, 40 mg of heavy oil was transferred to 8 ml vials. Then, 5 µl of a mixed standard containing squalane, D8 naphthalene, D10 phenanthrene and 1,1-biphenyl were added to each vial. The samples were divided into hydrocarbon and non-hydrocarbon fractions through solid phase extraction (SPE). To distinguish between aromatic and saturated hydrocarbon fractions, a modified Bastow method was adopted38. As a chromatographic column filled with 200 mesh activated silica gel, the stationary phase was formed after wetting with n-hexane. Saturated hydrocarbon components: Elution with 8 mL of n-hexane to collect all effluent. Aromatic hydrocarbon components: Subsequently elution with 8 mL of a mixture of n-hexane/dichloromethane (volume ratio 7:3). Polar components: Finally elution with 8 mL dichloromethane/methanol mixture (1:1 volume ratio). Duplicates and blanks were also analyzed for quality control.

sec.title: Analysis and quantification of crude oil molecular markers
sec.p: Hydrocarbon component analysis was performed using an Agilent 5975 C MSD system connected to an Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph. The saturated hydrocarbon fraction was analyzed using a DB-1MS fused silica capillary column (a film sized 60 m × 0.32 mm i.d × 0.25 μm). Also, the aromatic fraction was analyzed using an HP-5MS column (60 m × 0.32 m × 0.25 μm). The temperature inside the oven was set to increase from 40 °C to 325 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min, and it was held at 325 °C for 20 min. The flow rate of helium as the carrier gas was set to 1 ml/min. The temperature of the injector and the interface was maintained at 300 °C, and that of the transfer line was set to 250 °C. With the temperature of the ion source set to 230 °C, electron ionization (EI) was performed at 70 eV for ionization. Through selective ion monitoring (SIM), the sample was analyzed. The peak areas were integrated and quantified to the corresponding standards for identifying each component.

sec.title: Data processing and model setup
sec.p: There were 85 aromatic hydrocarbon components in viscosity and heavy oil selected for treatment and analysis. Also, two factors were considered for the selection of quantitative data of aromatic hydrocarbons. On the one hand, the force of interaction between saturated hydrocarbon molecules is weak, and the molecular structure is relatively simple. In contrast, there are more carbon atoms and polycyclic structures in aromatic hydrocarbons, π-π interaction is more intense between the molecules, and tighter chemical properties lead to a higher viscosity39. On the other hand, aromatic hydrocarbons contain a wide range of heterocyclic compounds, such as thiophene, pyridine, furan, etc. Besides, their biodegradation is more complex relative to hydrocarbons. From a chemical point of view, this difference hinders conventional mathematical models from capturing their intrinsic association with statistical variations. After the collection of the quantitative data on different molecular biomarkers in crude oil, the model was constructed using a joint prediction method based on ridge regression and neural network. Ridge Regression is a linear regression model that solves the multicollinearity problem by introducing L2 regularization terms to enhance the robustness and generalization ability of the model. The L2 regularization term is a penalty term in the model that limits the size of the regression coefficient. Its core function is to introduce L2 regularization term on the basis of least square regression, which is used to solve the problems of multicollinearity and high-dimensional small sample overfitting40. It was compared with the single feedforward neural network prediction method. All the codes were implemented in Matlab. Firstly, the data were normalized, and then the normalization function was applied to normalize the independent variable to a range of 0–1. In order to determine the regularization parameter λ used for ridge regression, cross-validation was performed with the average RSME value of the overall model as the target. Also, ridge regression fitting was performed after optimization of the ridge regression parameter λ, with a regression coefficient vector obtained. Subsequently, the fitting result of ridge regression was taken as the input of the neural network. The structure and training options of the neural network were defined. The neural network consisted of an input layer, three fully connected layers, three activation layers and an output layer. The size of the input layer was set to 15 and the size of the output layer was set to 1. In the first fully connected layer, there were 28 neurons. In the second and third fully connected layers, there were 14 neurons each. In the activation layer, ReLU function was used. By using Adam optimizer, the maximum number of iterations was set to 100, the mini-batch size was set to 32, and the initial learning rate was set to 0.01. On this basis, the data were randomly shuffled and validated during each iteration. Finally, cross-validation method was used to randomly divide the data into training set and test set. With the neural network trained and predicted respectively, the mean square error was calculated as an indicator used to evaluate the model’s performance.

sec.title: Reverse prediction
sec.p: After the neural network model was established, the correlation characteristics of crude oil biomarkers and viscosity were reversely mapped. Then, the model was used to predict the dibenzothiophene and triargonane series. The purpose of selecting these molecular markers is to obtain a different pattern of biodegradation to other molecular markers. This is due to the differences in the law of biodegradation41,42.
